(6) Humans: User Interface (UI)



What is an API? Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(7) Machines: Application Programming Interface (API)



What is an API? Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(8) Use Case #1: Integration

  • Many different systems have to be interconnected
  • Traditional integration essentially creates many 1:1 connections
  • API-led integration essentially creates one 1:n connection


What is an API? Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(9) Use Case #1: Automation

  • Being able to automate processes across individual capabilities
  • RPA allows automation but typically is brittle
  • APIs support robust automation across all API-enabled capabilities


What is an API? Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(10) Use Case #1: Reuse

  • Large organizations run the risk of reinventing the wheel
  • Large organizations run the risk of missing cross-pollination
  • APIs produce value based on usage, so reuse should be a strategic goal


Myth #1: APIs are about Technology

Myth #1: APIs are about Technology Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(12) A Brief History of APIs

  • Local APIs have been used since the 1940s
  • Network APIs have been used since the 1950s
  • Network APIs used to be called Protocols
  • Salesforce launched what they called APIs in February 2000
  • eBay launched their APIs in November 2000


Myth #1: APIs are about Technology Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(13) APIs Create Modular and Scalable Businesses

  • Digital Transformation
  • Move fast and break things
  • Loose coupling
  • The composable enterprise
  • The platform economy
  • The hockey stick


Myth #1: APIs are about Technology Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(14) Digital Transformation Definition

Digital Transformation means adapting an organization's strategy and structure to capture opportunities enabled by digital technology. (Nathan Furr and Andrew Shipilov, Digital Doesn't Have to Be Disruptive, Harvard Business Review 97(4), July/August 2019, pp. 94-103) [https://hbr.org/2019/07/digital-doesnt-have-to-be-disruptive]

Myth #2: API Monetization Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(20) Most API Value Creation is Indirect

  1. Using APIs to become better at internal reuse and cross-pollination
  2. Reducing friction by having teams communicate via APIs
  3. Using API First as a way to build everything as digital building blocks

Myth #3: API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(22) What is a Platform?

  1. A runtime platform that provides support for running applications
  2. A service platform for developing decentralized applications
  3. A business platform as a specific way to run & scale a business


Myth #3: API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(23) (One) Platform Definition

A platform is a business model that facilitates the exchange of value between two or more user groups, a consumer and a producer. In order to make these exchanges happen, platforms harness and create large, scalable networks of users and resources that can be accessed on demand. Platforms create communities and markets that allow users to interact and transact. […] Platforms don't, to use a common phrase, own the means of production—instead, they create the means of connection. (Alex Moazed and Nicholas L. Johnson, Modern Monopolies, St. Martin's Press, 2016 [https://us.macmillan.com/books/9781250091901/modernmonopolies])



Myth #3: API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(24) But we're not Uber…

  • Pure platform businesses are fascinating but rare
  • Find a way how to create platformish parts of your value streams
  • Business input is essential and APIs are just the means to an end

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs

(26) Got Strategy?

  • APIs are essential for businesses today
  • APIs should be treated as strategic business assets
  • APIs don't just happen but need to be strategically managed


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Three Myths About APIs
